comment.author: 38566845@N00
comment._content:
I can't identify what's being lifted by the crane on the right, but it doesn't look like a capsized ferry to me.

The tower on the left looks like it might be a pile driver. It is presumably constructing the offshore moorings near Athol Bay that for several decades were used to moor military vessels.

comment.author: 49015875@N00
comment._content:
if it is the Rodney then 

"13 February – Nineteen people die when Sydney ferry the Rodney, carrying 150 passengers, capsizes in Sydney Harbour while farewelling US Navy cruiser USS Louisville." from wikipedia

comment.author: 59531730@N02
comment._content: is this the one , my mum said every body rushed to one side and the ferry tipped over ?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/59531730@N02] That's correct heather1305. 

On 13 February 1938 a crowd of spectators onboard the ferry RODNEY were farewelling the USS LOUISVILLE in Sydney Harbour. It was top heavy and as passengers ran to one side of the ferry it capsized off Bradleys Head. Over 200 people were onboard, and 19 people drowned, with LOUISVILLE participating in the rescue efforts.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
